title: Records of Communications Between Secretary Kristi Noem and Dragoș Sprînceană (Feb-May 2025)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. All records reflecting any meeting, discussion, or communication (including but not limited to emails, text messages, messaging applications, call logs, calendar entries, briefing materials, memoranda, notes, or summaries) between Secretary Kristi Noem (or her office/staff) and Dragoș Sprînceană between February 1, 2025, and May 31, 2025.

2. All records reflecting discussions or deliberations concerning US-Romanian relations or Romania’s Visa Waiver Program status that reference or involve Dragoș Sprînceană during the same time period.

3. All calendars, visitor logs, call sheets, or scheduling records for Secretary Kristi Noem that reference or could reflect any official interaction with Dragoș Sprînceană between February 1, 2025, and May 31, 2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John Swoop

title: Haunani-Kay Trask (October 3, 1949 – July 3, 2021)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Haunani-Kay Trask (October 3, 1949 – July 3, 2021)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Professor Haunani-Kay Trask (October 3, 1949 – July 3, 2021). Her death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find her New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/09/us/haunani-kay-trask-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an assistant editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Records concerning Commissioner Trey Trainor's Romania Election Observation Visit (2025)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records concerning Commissioner Trey Trainor's Romania Election Observation Visit (2025)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Records related to former FEC Commissioner James Edwin “Trey” Trainor III’s visit to Romania in May 2025, for the period January 1, 2025 through July 31, 2025. This request includes, but is not limited to:
a. Names, positions, and roles of all staff, participants, consultants, or accompanying personnel involved in the visit.
b. Memos, emails, or other documentation describing the circumstances under which each staff member was appointed or assigned to participate.
c. Travel authorizations, itineraries, per diem approvals, and any other logistical documentation associated with the visit.
d. Correspondence with the U.S. State Department, Romanian officials, or any other agencies regarding staff selection, participation, or planning of the visit.
e. Reports, summaries, evaluations, or notes documenting the meetings, observations, or outcomes of the visit, whether produced for internal or external purposes.
f. Internal briefings, instructions, or reports provided to staff before, during, or after the visit.
g. Whether the FEC endorsed, supported, or adopted any viewpoint, assessment, or conclusion regarding the May 2025 Romania election observation visit.
h. Any guidance, statements, or correspondence clarifying whether public remarks, interviews, or publications by Commissioner James Edwin “Trey” Trainor III or accompanying staff regarding the May 2025 Romania election observation visit are considered official FEC positions or attributable to the Commission.

For reference, the visit has been described on a Weekly Digest page as follows: "From May 2-5, Acting Chairman Trainor observed the Presidential elections in Romania."  https://www.fec.gov/updates/week-of-april-28-may-2-2025/

2. All records specifically concerning Dragoș Sprînceană, in connection with the above-referenced May 2025 Romania visit, election observation activities, or any other engagement, communication, or interaction with the Federal Election Commission from November 1, 2024 through October 31, 2025, including any records in which his name appears in variant spellings (e.g., “Dragos Sprinceana”, “Dragos Spranceana”).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John Swoop

title: Statutory Notice and Implementation Records (ORS 659A.279)

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Statutory Notice and Implementation Records (ORS 659A.279)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am submitting a public records request for records sufficient to demonstrate how the University of Oregon satisfies the statutory notice requirement under ORS 659A.279 for the safety-related leave protections set out in ORS 659A.270–659A.285.

To be clear, this request concerns the employer-administered statutory protection itself, which exists independently of the Paid Leave Oregon wage-replacement program and applies regardless of whether leave is paid or unpaid, including public-employer obligations such as the 160-hour leave bank.

Please provide records showing the following:

1. Notice content and location
•	The specific notice(s), webpage(s), posting(s), or written materials the University relies on to “summarize the provisions” of ORS 659A.270–659A.285, as required by ORS 659A.279;
•	Where those notices are posted or maintained, including physical locations and URLs;
•	The date each notice or posting went into effect and any revisions made since 2019.

2. Procedures available to employees
•	Any written procedures, guidance, or internal instructions explaining how an employee invokes the statutory protection with the University;
•	Identification of the office(s) responsible for administering the protection;
•	Policies or guidance explaining how the protection functions when Paid Leave Oregon benefits are unavailable, exhausted, or not applicable;
•	Any materials intended to allow employees to plan around the protection, including timing, documentation, duration, and job-protection effects.

3. Transition and change records (2019–2026)
•	Records documenting the transition from earlier certification forms and processes in use in or around 2019 to later versions used in 2026;
•	Any drafts, approvals, internal communications, or decision-making records associated with revising or replacing those forms or procedures;
•	Records reflecting how the University evaluated whether revised forms, postings, or procedures continued to comply with ORS 659A.279 following the implementation of Paid Leave Oregon;
•	Any records addressing how employees were notified of changes in forms, routing, or administration.
•	Any written policies, procedures, workflows, routing instructions, or standard operating procedures used by Human Resources, HR Leaves, or other offices when an employee requests safety-related leave and Paid Leave Oregon benefits are unavailable or exhausted, including records addressing whether and how the employee is routed to University-administered unpaid leave or the 160-hour public-employer leave bank.

If the University contends that no responsive records exist for any portion of this request, please confirm that position in writing.

Clarification regarding parallel processes:

To avoid any confusion, this public records request is submitted pursuant to Oregon Public Records Law only and does not waive, replace, or otherwise affect any requests, grievances, or RFIs I have submitted through my union or any other employment-related process, many of which remain pending.

This request is submitted because I require timely access to records necessary to understand my statutory protections and to plan accordingly. The public records process is the only mechanism currently available to obtain this information within a reasonable timeframe.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Kelvin Shivers II

title: PIO City of Austin: Free USA Foundation  (Russian: СVободные Штаты Америки) Documents Regarding Austin City Hall protest 9/30/2022

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: PIO City of Austin: Free USA Foundation  (Russian: СVободные Штаты Америки) Documents Regarding Austin City Hall protest 9/30/2022
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

To the Public Information Officer of the City of Austin: I am seeking records related to a security tip and subsequent law enforcement monitoring of a planned protest at Austin City Hall on September 30, 2022.

Context:
On September 29, 2022, the Texas Fusion Center was alerted to a Russian-language Telegram account called the "Free USA Foundation" (Russian: СVободные Штаты Америки). This account was actively recruiting protesters to gather at Austin City Hall on September 30, 2022, at 6 PM, utilizing pro-Kremlin rhetoric and "Thin Blue Line" imagery.

Images of this account are preserved online at the Internet Archive: 
https://web.archive.org/web/20220929131546/https://t.me/freeusafoundation/18

Original URL:
https://t.me/freeusafoundation

Records Requested
I respectfully request the following information from the Austin Police Department (APD) and the City of Austin for the period of September 20, 2022, to October 15, 2022:

Intelligence & Incident Reports: Any incident reports, "Significant Event" summaries, or intelligence briefings regarding the planned protest at Austin City Hall on September 30, 2022, specifically mentioning the "Free USA Foundation" or Russian-language recruitment efforts.

Communications with the Texas Fusion Center: All emails or digital communications between APD (including the Intelligence Unit or Special Events Unit) and the Texas Fusion Center (TXFC) or the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) regarding this tip or the security of Austin City Hall on that date.

Real-Time Tactical Communications: Any computer-aided dispatch (CAD) logs or tactical memos created by officers assigned to monitor the City Hall area on September 30, 2022, in response to the reported "Free USA Foundation" threat.

Social Media Monitoring Records: Any records of monitoring conducted by APD’s intelligence or social media units regarding the Telegram handle freeusafoundation.

Adler Emails: Emails to or from (to, cc, bcc) steve.adler@austintexas.gov where "Free USA Foundation" or the URL of: https://t.me/freeusafoundation appears in the subject line or body of the email. 

If certain parts of this request or certain portions must be redacted please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

Thank you for the city of Austin's commitment to transparency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: TXFC: Free USA Foundation (СVободные Штаты Америки) Telegram Account and Austin Protest Call

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: TXFC: Free USA Foundation (СVободные Штаты Америки) Telegram Account and Austin Protest Call
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking access to and copies of records maintained by the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) and the Texas Fusion Center (TXFC) related to a specific report of potential foreign influence and propaganda activities. 

Background Information

On or about September 29, 2022, a tip was submitted to the Texas Fusion Center (TXFC@dps.texas.gov) by a Robert "Robby" Delaware regarding a Russian-language Telegram account named "Free USA Foundation" (СVободные Штаты Америки). The report detailed efforts by this account to recruit protesters for a gathering at Austin City Hall on September 30, 2022, and highlighted the account's use of pro-Kremlin rhetoric and "Thin Blue Line" imagery to incite civil discord in Texas. 

One image of this account was preserved online via the Internet Archive:

https://web.archive.org/web/20220929131546/https://t.me/freeusafoundation/18

Original URLs:
https://t.me/freeusafoundation
https://t.me/freeusafoundation/18

Records Requested
I respectfully request the following records created, received, or maintained between September 20, 2022, and the present:

Communications & Internal Logs: Any internal emails, logs, or notes from the Texas Fusion Center or DPS personnel regarding the tip received from Robert "Robby" Delaware on September 29, 2022.

Intelligence Products: Any bulletins, "Situational Awareness" alerts, "Blue Notes," or intelligence summaries generated by the TXFC or DPS that mention the "Free USA Foundation," "СVободные Штаты Америки,", the specific URL of https://t.me/freeusafoundation or the proposed Austin City Hall protest on September 30, 2022.

Third-Party Correspondence: All correspondence between the Texas Department of Public Safety/Texas Fusion Center and Telegram Messenger Inc. (or its legal/compliance departments) regarding the removal or investigation of the "Free USA Foundation" accounts.

Inter-Agency Shared Info: Any communications with the FBI or the City of Austin (including Austin Police Department) regarding this specific Telegram network and its attempts to organize in Texas.

If certain parts of this request or certain portions must be redacted please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

Thank you to the Texas Fusion Center for the Center's commitment to transparency and for the work the center does every day.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: California official reports RFP, agreements, correspondence (Supreme Court of California)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California official reports RFP, agreements, correspondence (Supreme Court of California)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The below requests are all in connection with the California Supreme Court's Request for Proposal RFP-CAL-2023-01-RP for publication of the California official reports (the "RFP"), made under Government Code section 68903, and which is available at https://courts.ca.gov/request/rfp-cal-2023-01-rp/rfp/publication-california-official-reports.

Government Code section 68903 states:

"The official reports shall be published under a contract to be entered into on behalf of the state by the Chief Justice of California, the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the President of the State Bar, and the Reporter of Decisions, who shall serve as secretary."

REQUESTS:

1. All signed agreements made under proposals received pursuant to the RFP, including subsequent signed amendments (collectively, the "Agreements").
2. All correspondence with LexisNexis about the RFP.
3. All correspondence with LexisNexis about the Agreements.
4. All proposals received in response to the RFP.
5. All internal correspondence related to the RFP.

If assessing any confidentiality concerns, please note the following language in the RFP:

11.0 CONFIDENTIAL OR PROPRIETARY INFORMATION
PROPOSALS ARE SUBJECT TO DISCLOSURE TO THIRD PARTIES AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC PURSUANT TO APPLICABLE LAWS, INCLUDING PUBLIC DISCLOSURE PURSUANT TO RULE 10.500 OF THE CALIFORNIA RULES OF COURT. Except as required by law, neither the Judicial Council nor the Court will disclose (i) social security numbers, or (ii) balance sheets or income statements submitted by a Publisher that is not a publicly traded corporation. All other information in Proposals may be disclosed in response to applicable public records requests, or as otherwise required by law. Such disclosure may be made regardless of whether the Proposal (or portions thereof) is marked “confidential,” “proprietary,” “copyright ©,” or otherwise, and regardless of any statement in the Proposal (a) purporting to limit the Judicial Council’s or Court’s right to disclose information in the Proposal, or (b) requiring the Judicial Council or Court to inform or obtain the consent of the Publisher prior to the disclosure of the Proposal (or portions thereof). Any Proposal that is password protected, or contains portions that are password protected, may be rejected. Submission of any Proposal pursuant to this RFP constitutes acknowledgment and consent by the Publisher to the potential public disclosure of its Proposal content, as set forth in this section. Publishers are accordingly cautioned not to include confidential, proprietary, or privileged information in proposals.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available, or by USB drive, CD-ROM, or online file sharing system if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ansel Halliburton

communications.subject: Thank you for your request. (Autoreply)
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting the Judicial Council of California’s Public Access to Judicial Administrative Records (PAJAR) team. This message is an automatic reply to let you know that we received your request.

Please read the message below because it has information that may help you.

*** PLEASE DO NOT REPLY to this e-mail message. Responses to this automatic reply are not monitored.***

WHAT TO EXPECT


  *   If you are asking for court case records—for example, a court order, divorce records, name change records, criminal history records— this message will be the only response you receive. Please read the section below, The PAJAR Team Cannot Provide These Records, to find information that may be helpful.


  *   If you are asking for judicial administrative records from the Judicial Council, the Supreme Court of California, or a California Court of Appeal, the PAJAR team will send you a response within about 10 days.


  *   Here are some examples of judicial administrative records: signed contracts, final audit reports, budget and spending reports, reports to the Legislature, and procurement records. You can find more information about judicial administrative records at courts.ca.gov/cms/rules/index/ten/rule10_500<https://courts.ca.gov/cms/rules/index/ten/rule10_500> and at courts.ca.gov/policy-administration/public-records<https://courts.ca.gov/policy-administration/public-records>.


  *   The PAJAR team may ask you for more information to be sure it understands your request. The PAJAR team may also notify you if it needs more time to complete a search.


  *   When work on your request is complete, the PAJAR team will notify you whether there are disclosable responsive records or not. If there are disclosable responsive copies, the PAJAR team will provide electronic copies, if possible.

THE PAJAR TEAM CANNOT PROVIDE THESE RECORDS

>   Court Case Records—Superior Courts of California

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of superior court case records. If you want records filed in a specific superior court case, you must contact the court directly. California has 58 superior courts, one in each county. You can find links to each court’s website at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Each superior court clerk is responsible for that court’s records.

Some superior court websites allow the public to search and view some types of case records online. If a court’s website does not allow you to search and view case records online, you must call or visit the court clerk’s office for help. Superior courts post their telephone numbers and street addresses on their websites. Some also post e-mail addresses.

Examples of records that you must request by contacting a superior court:

·         Divorce decrees;

·         Traffic citations;

·         Name change records;

·         Wills;

·         Criminal case records (for example, orders imposing sentences and judgments); and

·         Restraining orders.

You will find more information about some of these topics in the message below.

>   Court Case Records—Supreme Court of California and California Courts of Appeal

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of appellate court case records. You can find information about specific cases filed with the Supreme Court of California or with the California Courts of Appeal at appellatecases.courtinfo.ca.gov<http://appellatecases.courtinfo.ca.gov/>.

You can review opinions that the Supreme Court of California and the California Courts of Appeal issued in specific cases at courts.ca.gov/opinions.htm<http://www.courts.ca.gov/opinions.htm>.

You can find the following Supreme Court of California case records online:

·         Legal briefs filed in cases argued before the court: supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/briefs-argued-cases<https://supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/briefs-argued-cases>; and

·         Official minutes going back three years: supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/minutes<https://supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/minutes>.

To view or request copies of records filed in a specific case before the Supreme Court of California, you must call or visit the court. Supreme Court contact information is posted at supreme.courts.ca.gov/about-court/court-locations-and-contacts<https://supreme.courts.ca.gov/about-court/court-locations-and-contacts>.

To view or request copies of records filed in specific cases before a California Court of Appeal you must call or visit the court. You can find a list of the six Courts of Appeal at appellate.courts.ca.gov<https://appellate.courts.ca.gov/>. On the left side of that page, select the court where the case is filed. Then scroll down to select “Contact Us.” On that page you will find court telephone numbers and location addresses.

If you have a Court of Appeal case number, but you do not know the court where the case is filed, please visit appellate.courts.ca.gov<https://appellate.courts.ca.gov/>. That page lists the letters that begin the case numbers for each of the Courts of Appeal.

Information about California appellate court cases also is available at your local law library, which may provide free public access to computer-assisted legal research systems such as LexisNexis or Westlaw. To learn more about local public law libraries, and to locate one near you, visit selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/court-basics/law-libraries<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/court-basics/law-libraries>.

>   Court Case Records—United States Federal Courts


The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of records filed in cases before federal courts located in California. To find information about those federal courts—including court telephone numbers and location addresses for those courts—please visit:

  *   www.cand.uscourts.gov<http://www.cand.uscourts.gov> (district court, Northern California);
  *   www.casd.uscourts.gov<http://www.casd.uscourts.gov> (district court, Southern California);
  *   www.caed.uscourts.gov<http://www.caed.uscourts.gov> (district court, Eastern California);
  *   www.cacd.uscourts.gov<http://www.cacd.uscourts.gov> (district court, Central California); and
  *   www.ca9.uscourts.gov<http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov> (Courts of Appeal).

>   Birth or Death Certificates

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of birth or death certificates. The registrar or recorder in the county where the birth or death occurred would have these records.

You can find a list of all California county registrars and recorders, and their contact information, at www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/County-Registrars-and-Recorders.aspx<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/County-Registrars-and-Recorders.aspx>.

For information about how to request a birth or death certificate, please visit the website of California’s Department of Public Health, at www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/Vital-Records.aspx<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/Vital-Records.aspx>.

>   Domestic Violence Information

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of restraining or protective orders. You can find Information about where and how to ask for help in domestic violence circumstances on the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/DV-restraining-order<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/DV-restraining-order>.

If you want copies of a restraining or protective order, you must contact the superior court where the case is filed. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

>   Criminal Background Records

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of criminal history records. You must request copies from the superior court where the criminal case is filed. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

Federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies are responsible for investigating criminal activity. If you suspect criminal activity is taking place, please contact law enforcement authorities. You can find a list of California Law Enforcement Agencies at post.ca.gov/le-agencies<https://post.ca.gov/le-agencies>.

>   Name Change Records

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of name change records. The California State Archives stores some name change records. Please visit the State Archives website, at www.sos.ca.gov/archives/about-archives/contact<http://www.sos.ca.gov/archives/about-archives/contact/> to learn more. You can also call the California State Archives reference desk at 916-653-2246.

Information about the process for completing a name change can be found on the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/name-change<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/name-change>.

>   Traffic Citations

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of traffic citations. Each superior court handles traffic matters independently and is responsible for its own records. If you have questions about a traffic ticket, please contact the superior court listed on the ticket (i.e., the “Notice to Appear”). You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

You can find general information about traffic tickets on the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/traffic<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/traffic>.

>   Wills

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of a will for someone who has died. If a copy of the will has been filed or lodged with a superior court, you must contact the superior court to request a copy. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

For general information about wills, estates, and probate matters, please visit the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/wills-estates-probate<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/wills-estates-probate>.

>   Jury Duty Information

The PAJAR team cannot answer questions about jury duty. If you have questions about a juror summons, or want to be excused from jury duty, please contact the superior court that issued the jury summons. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. This page also contains links to the pages on each court’s website that has information about juror service. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

You can find general information about jury service in California by visiting courts.ca.gov/courts/jury-service<https://courts.ca.gov/courts/jury-service>.

We hope this information is helpful. Thank you for your interest in the California judicial branch.

Sincerely,
Public Access to Judicial Administrative Records
Legal Services | Leadership Services Division
Judicial Council of California
455 Golden Gate Avenue
San Francisco, California 94102-3688

title: California official reports RFP, agreements, correspondence (Judicial Council of California)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California official reports RFP, agreements, correspondence (Judicial Council of California)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The below requests are all in connection with the California Supreme Court's Request for Proposal RFP-CAL-2023-01-RP for publication of the California official reports (the "RFP"), made under Government Code section 68903, and which is available at https://courts.ca.gov/request/rfp-cal-2023-01-rp/rfp/publication-california-official-reports.

Government Code section 68903 states:

"The official reports shall be published under a contract to be entered into on behalf of the state by the Chief Justice of California, the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the President of the State Bar, and the Reporter of Decisions, who shall serve as secretary."

REQUESTS:

1. All signed agreements made under proposals received pursuant to the RFP, including subsequent signed amendments (collectively, the "Agreements").
2. All correspondence with LexisNexis about the RFP.
3. All correspondence with LexisNexis about the Agreements.
4. All proposals received in response to the RFP.
5. All internal correspondence related to the RFP.

If assessing any confidentiality concerns, please note the following language in the RFP:

11.0 CONFIDENTIAL OR PROPRIETARY INFORMATION
PROPOSALS ARE SUBJECT TO DISCLOSURE TO THIRD PARTIES AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC PURSUANT TO APPLICABLE LAWS, INCLUDING PUBLIC DISCLOSURE PURSUANT TO RULE 10.500 OF THE CALIFORNIA RULES OF COURT. Except as required by law, neither the Judicial Council nor the Court will disclose (i) social security numbers, or (ii) balance sheets or income statements submitted by a Publisher that is not a publicly traded corporation. All other information in Proposals may be disclosed in response to applicable public records requests, or as otherwise required by law. Such disclosure may be made regardless of whether the Proposal (or portions thereof) is marked “confidential,” “proprietary,” “copyright ©,” or otherwise, and regardless of any statement in the Proposal (a) purporting to limit the Judicial Council’s or Court’s right to disclose information in the Proposal, or (b) requiring the Judicial Council or Court to inform or obtain the consent of the Publisher prior to the disclosure of the Proposal (or portions thereof). Any Proposal that is password protected, or contains portions that are password protected, may be rejected. Submission of any Proposal pursuant to this RFP constitutes acknowledgment and consent by the Publisher to the potential public disclosure of its Proposal content, as set forth in this section. Publishers are accordingly cautioned not to include confidential, proprietary, or privileged information in proposals.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available, or by USB drive, CD-ROM, or online file sharing system if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ansel Halliburton

communications.subject: Thank you for your request. (Autoreply)
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting the Judicial Council of California’s Public Access to Judicial Administrative Records (PAJAR) team. This message is an automatic reply to let you know that we received your request.

Please read the message below because it has information that may help you.

*** PLEASE DO NOT REPLY to this e-mail message. Responses to this automatic reply are not monitored.***

WHAT TO EXPECT


  *   If you are asking for court case records—for example, a court order, divorce records, name change records, criminal history records— this message will be the only response you receive. Please read the section below, The PAJAR Team Cannot Provide These Records, to find information that may be helpful.


  *   If you are asking for judicial administrative records from the Judicial Council, the Supreme Court of California, or a California Court of Appeal, the PAJAR team will send you a response within about 10 days.


  *   Here are some examples of judicial administrative records: signed contracts, final audit reports, budget and spending reports, reports to the Legislature, and procurement records. You can find more information about judicial administrative records at courts.ca.gov/cms/rules/index/ten/rule10_500<https://courts.ca.gov/cms/rules/index/ten/rule10_500> and at courts.ca.gov/policy-administration/public-records<https://courts.ca.gov/policy-administration/public-records>.


  *   The PAJAR team may ask you for more information to be sure it understands your request. The PAJAR team may also notify you if it needs more time to complete a search.


  *   When work on your request is complete, the PAJAR team will notify you whether there are disclosable responsive records or not. If there are disclosable responsive copies, the PAJAR team will provide electronic copies, if possible.

THE PAJAR TEAM CANNOT PROVIDE THESE RECORDS

>   Court Case Records—Superior Courts of California

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of superior court case records. If you want records filed in a specific superior court case, you must contact the court directly. California has 58 superior courts, one in each county. You can find links to each court’s website at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Each superior court clerk is responsible for that court’s records.

Some superior court websites allow the public to search and view some types of case records online. If a court’s website does not allow you to search and view case records online, you must call or visit the court clerk’s office for help. Superior courts post their telephone numbers and street addresses on their websites. Some also post e-mail addresses.

Examples of records that you must request by contacting a superior court:

·         Divorce decrees;

·         Traffic citations;

·         Name change records;

·         Wills;

·         Criminal case records (for example, orders imposing sentences and judgments); and

·         Restraining orders.

You will find more information about some of these topics in the message below.

>   Court Case Records—Supreme Court of California and California Courts of Appeal

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of appellate court case records. You can find information about specific cases filed with the Supreme Court of California or with the California Courts of Appeal at appellatecases.courtinfo.ca.gov<http://appellatecases.courtinfo.ca.gov/>.

You can review opinions that the Supreme Court of California and the California Courts of Appeal issued in specific cases at courts.ca.gov/opinions.htm<http://www.courts.ca.gov/opinions.htm>.

You can find the following Supreme Court of California case records online:

·         Legal briefs filed in cases argued before the court: supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/briefs-argued-cases<https://supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/briefs-argued-cases>; and

·         Official minutes going back three years: supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/minutes<https://supreme.courts.ca.gov/case-information/minutes>.

To view or request copies of records filed in a specific case before the Supreme Court of California, you must call or visit the court. Supreme Court contact information is posted at supreme.courts.ca.gov/about-court/court-locations-and-contacts<https://supreme.courts.ca.gov/about-court/court-locations-and-contacts>.

To view or request copies of records filed in specific cases before a California Court of Appeal you must call or visit the court. You can find a list of the six Courts of Appeal at appellate.courts.ca.gov<https://appellate.courts.ca.gov/>. On the left side of that page, select the court where the case is filed. Then scroll down to select “Contact Us.” On that page you will find court telephone numbers and location addresses.

If you have a Court of Appeal case number, but you do not know the court where the case is filed, please visit appellate.courts.ca.gov<https://appellate.courts.ca.gov/>. That page lists the letters that begin the case numbers for each of the Courts of Appeal.

Information about California appellate court cases also is available at your local law library, which may provide free public access to computer-assisted legal research systems such as LexisNexis or Westlaw. To learn more about local public law libraries, and to locate one near you, visit selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/court-basics/law-libraries<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/court-basics/law-libraries>.

>   Court Case Records—United States Federal Courts


The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of records filed in cases before federal courts located in California. To find information about those federal courts—including court telephone numbers and location addresses for those courts—please visit:

  *   www.cand.uscourts.gov<http://www.cand.uscourts.gov> (district court, Northern California);
  *   www.casd.uscourts.gov<http://www.casd.uscourts.gov> (district court, Southern California);
  *   www.caed.uscourts.gov<http://www.caed.uscourts.gov> (district court, Eastern California);
  *   www.cacd.uscourts.gov<http://www.cacd.uscourts.gov> (district court, Central California); and
  *   www.ca9.uscourts.gov<http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov> (Courts of Appeal).

>   Birth or Death Certificates

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of birth or death certificates. The registrar or recorder in the county where the birth or death occurred would have these records.

You can find a list of all California county registrars and recorders, and their contact information, at www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/County-Registrars-and-Recorders.aspx<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/County-Registrars-and-Recorders.aspx>.

For information about how to request a birth or death certificate, please visit the website of California’s Department of Public Health, at www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/Vital-Records.aspx<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CHSI/Pages/Vital-Records.aspx>.

>   Domestic Violence Information

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of restraining or protective orders. You can find Information about where and how to ask for help in domestic violence circumstances on the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/DV-restraining-order<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/DV-restraining-order>.

If you want copies of a restraining or protective order, you must contact the superior court where the case is filed. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

>   Criminal Background Records

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of criminal history records. You must request copies from the superior court where the criminal case is filed. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

Federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies are responsible for investigating criminal activity. If you suspect criminal activity is taking place, please contact law enforcement authorities. You can find a list of California Law Enforcement Agencies at post.ca.gov/le-agencies<https://post.ca.gov/le-agencies>.

>   Name Change Records

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of name change records. The California State Archives stores some name change records. Please visit the State Archives website, at www.sos.ca.gov/archives/about-archives/contact<http://www.sos.ca.gov/archives/about-archives/contact/> to learn more. You can also call the California State Archives reference desk at 916-653-2246.

Information about the process for completing a name change can be found on the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/name-change<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/name-change>.

>   Traffic Citations

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of traffic citations. Each superior court handles traffic matters independently and is responsible for its own records. If you have questions about a traffic ticket, please contact the superior court listed on the ticket (i.e., the “Notice to Appear”). You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

You can find general information about traffic tickets on the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/traffic<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/traffic>.

>   Wills

The PAJAR team cannot provide copies of a will for someone who has died. If a copy of the will has been filed or lodged with a superior court, you must contact the superior court to request a copy. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

For general information about wills, estates, and probate matters, please visit the California Courts Self-Help website at selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/wills-estates-probate<https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/wills-estates-probate>.

>   Jury Duty Information

The PAJAR team cannot answer questions about jury duty. If you have questions about a juror summons, or want to be excused from jury duty, please contact the superior court that issued the jury summons. You can find links to all 58 superior court websites at courts.ca.gov/find-my-court<https://courts.ca.gov/find-my-court>. This page also contains links to the pages on each court’s website that has information about juror service. Court websites list court telephone numbers and locations.

You can find general information about jury service in California by visiting courts.ca.gov/courts/jury-service<https://courts.ca.gov/courts/jury-service>.

We hope this information is helpful. Thank you for your interest in the California judicial branch.

Sincerely,
Public Access to Judicial Administrative Records
Legal Services | Leadership Services Division
Judicial Council of California
455 Golden Gate Avenue
San Francisco, California 94102-3688
415-865-7796 | PAJAR@jud.ca.gov<mailto:PAJAR@jud.ca.gov> | courts.ca.gov/policy-administration/public-records<https://courts.ca.gov/policy-administration/public-records>

title: Founding Records of the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) Program (1999) - DARPA

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Founding Records of the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) Program (1999) - DARPA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The original Task Order or Statement of Work (SOW) issued to The MITRE Corporation in 1999, specifically authorizing the creation, development, and/or maintenance of the "Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures" (CVE) list/program. Additionally, any documents around the budget, money allocations, and/or expenditures for the program for the years DARPA funded the program, before it was funded by DHS. I believe this to be from 1999 - 2003.

Record Description Clues: The CVE program was publicly launched in September 1999 following a white paper by David E. Mann and Steven M. Christey.  The 1999 DARPA "Information Assurance" (IA) Program authorization documents that funded MITRE’s work on "common taxonomies" or "vulnerability enumerations" under the Air Force Electronic Systems Center (ESC) master contract.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Suspension of Food Service License for Hat City Ale House issued by Lisa Morrissey without due process August 2018 (Health And Human Services Danbury)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. THE "ORDER OF THE DIRECTOR OF HEALTH SUSPENSION OF FOOD SERVICE LICENSE" NATIVE FILE A copy of the native electronic file (original .doc, .docx, or .pdf format) for the document titled or known as the "ORDER OF THE DIRECTOR OF HEALTH SUSPENSION OF FOOD SERVICE LICENSE" authored by Lisa Morrissey, Health Department Director and prepared by Fernada Carvalho as noted by initials on the face of the document regarding Hat City Ale House. A copy of the document is attached to this FOI request.

Special Requirement: I am specifically requesting the metadata associated with this file, including but not limited to: Date of Creation, Date of Last Modification, Authoring User, and File Path.

2. FILING AND AUDIT TRAIL RECORDS All records, including emails, internal memos, or "Records Disposal Authorizations" (Form RC-075), that document the date this document was placed into the physical folder of the Health Department.

3.  THE "CEASE AND DESIST" NATIVE FILE A copy of the native electronic file (original .doc, .docx, or .pdf format) for the document titled or known as the "CEASE AND DESIST" authored by Lisa Morrissey, Health Department Director and prepared by Fernada Carvalho as noted by initials on the face of the document regarding Hat City Ale House. A copy of the document is attached to this FOI request.

Special Requirement: I am specifically requesting the metadata associated with this file, including but not limited to: Date of Creation, Date of Last Modification, Authoring User, and File Path.

4. FILING AND AUDIT TRAIL RECORDS All records, including emails, internal memos, or "Records Disposal Authorizations" (Form RC-075), that document the date this document was placed into the physical folder of the Health Department.

5. All communications with the Connecticut Health Department in connection with the above referenced documents and Hat City Ale House from May 2018 to the present.

6. All copies of the above referenced documents in possession of Sean Hearty, both as Permit Center Director/Coordinator and Zoning Enforcement Officer, Danbury Planning and zoning.

Special Requirement: I am specifically requesting the metadata associated with these files, including but not limited to: Date of Creation, Date of Last Modification, Authoring User, and File Path.

7. FILING AND AUDIT TRAIL RECORDS All records, including emails, internal memos, or "Records Disposal Authorizations" (Form RC-075), that document the date this document was placed into the physical folder of the Health Department.

Records obtained recently from the Office of the Public Records Administrator show that the latest records destroyed by the Danbury Health Department are from 2017. If any of these requested records have been destroyed, please include the properly executed RC-075 documents. I am also requesting that the Health Department refrain from destroying any records in connection with Hat City Ale house, Kevin Paige, or Paige Enterprises, Inc. until the fulfillment of this request is considered complete by both parties.

Format: Per CGS § 1-212(g), I request these records in their original electronic format to preserve the integrity of the embedded metadata. Providing a scanned PDF or a paper printout of an electronic file is a "denial of access" to the metadata which is itself a public record.

Feel free to respond through this portal if there is any need for clarification of this request.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kevin Paige

I wanted to first thank your office for your continued cooperation with my requests, I appreciate the effort and work put into your department's responses. 

Pursuant to the Florida Public Records Law (Chapter 119, Florida Statutes), I hereby request the following records related to Okaloosa County Sheriff's Department's use of the FUSUS/Axon Real-Time Crime Center platform:

1. All contracts, licenses, MOUs, MOAs, data agreements, letters of intent, Statements of Work documents, Scope of Work documents, and other agreement documents with FUSUS/Axon related to FUSUS platform implementation or use.

2. Technical documentation showing what systems are integrated with or connect to FUSUS, including but not limited to: video surveillance systems, body-worn cameras, ALPR systems, facial recognition systems (including FACES), gunshot detection systems, drone systems, CAD systems, RMS systems, 911 systems, and any AI or machine learning tools.

3. List of agencies and organizations that have access to the department's FUSUS platform or whose FUSUS platforms the department can access.

This request does NOT seek personally identifiable information, photographs, video footage, biometric data, specific investigative techniques, or information that would compromise system security or ongoing investigations.

title: Altered Hat City Ale House Revised Plan of Operation presented by Dan Casagrande of Cramer & Anderson Law Firm

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Altered Hat City Ale House Revised Plan of Operation presented by Dan Casagrande of Cramer & Anderson Law Firm
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. THE "CASAGRANDE DRAFT" NATIVE FILE A copy of the native electronic file (original .doc, .docx, or .pdf format) for the document titled or known as the "Revised Statement of Planned BusinessOperation" authored by Attorney Dan Casagrande, which was recently located in the Health Department files regarding Hat City Ale House. A copy of the document is page 5 of the attached file and was returned in a prior FOI request on 1/5/26. This document bears my signature and was never submitted by me. Dan Casagrande presented this altered document in a discussion conference in January 2024. It was not marked for discussion or draft purposes. Who placed it in the file is unknown. It's existence was discovered by me on March 13, 2024. Upon which I notified Farley Santos of the Mayors staff. Farley Santos assured me that it had been removed/destroyed on or about March 21, 2024. It currently remains in the health department folder and does not represent statements I have ever submitted to the City of Danbury.

Special Requirement: I am specifically requesting the metadata associated with this file, including but not limited to: Date of Creation, Date of Last Modification, Authoring User, and File Path.

2. FILING AND AUDIT TRAIL RECORDS All records, including emails, internal memos, or "Records Disposal Authorizations" (Form RC-075), that document the date this document was placed into the physical folder of the Health Department.

3. 2018 INTAKE RECORDS The original 13-page "Intake Form" or inspection report from the 2018 initial issuance of Food Service License for Hat City Ale House. If this record has been destroyed, please provide the corresponding RC-075 form authorizing its destruction as required by the State Library’s retention schedule.

Format: Per CGS § 1-212(g), I request these records in their original electronic format to preserve the integrity of the embedded metadata. Providing a scanned PDF or a paper printout of an electronic file is a "denial of access" to the metadata which is itself a public record.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kevin Paige

This request is for any and all responsive records at all relevant department/agency offices and facilities including, but not limited to, headquarters.

In order to facilitate the location of the requested records I am providing the following list of names that may be associated with these allegations and any related Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) inquiry: Amir Gat, Sandra Troian, Daniel Weihs, Morteza Gharib, Kelly M. In order to help to determine my status to assess fees, you should know that I am a representative of the news media affiliated with the Randolph Bourne Institute and its media outlet, Antiwar.com. This request is made as part of news gathering and not for a commercial use.

title: Ohio Highway Shootings

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Ohio Highway Shootings
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting public records related to incidents of shootings and violence occurring on roadways under the jurisdiction of the Ohio State Highway Patrol (OSHP), including the Ohio Turnpike and Interstate Highway System. The date range for these records is from January 1, 2023, to December 31, 2025.

This request is divided into three parts: records identified by specific criminal statutes, records identified by a keyword search of narratives, and any existing compiled data.

PART 1: RECORDS BY STATUTE

Please provide all Incident Reports (OH-1 or OH-2 forms if applicable in this context) and Case Reports for cases where the Ohio State Highway Patrol was the primary investigating agency and charges were filed (or the incident was classified) under the following Ohio Revised Code (ORC) statutes.

Please limit results to incidents occurring on state highways, the Ohio Turnpike, or interstates.

HOMICIDE & ATTEMPTED HOMICIDE:
-- ORC § 2903.01 (Aggravated Murder)
-- ORC § 2903.02 (Murder)
-- ORC § 2923.02 / § 2903.02 (Attempted Murder)

ASSAULT, BATTERY & DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
-- ORC § 2903.11 (Felonious Assault - specifically (A)(2) Causing or attempting to cause physical harm to another by means of a deadly weapon or dangerous ordnance)
-- ORC § 2903.12 (Aggravated Assault - specifically (A)(2) involving a deadly weapon)
-- ORC § 2923.16 (Improperly handling firearms in a motor vehicle - specifically (A) Discharging a firearm while in or on a motor vehicle)

ROADWAY & VEHICULAR ENDANGERMENT:
-- ORC § 2903.08 (Aggravated vehicular assault)
-- ORC § 2917.11 (Disorderly Conduct - specifically if flagged with weapons modifiers)
-- ORC § 2903.21 (Aggravated Menacing - specifically involving brandishing of firearms in road rage incidents)

####

PART 2: RECORDS BY KEYWORD SEARCH

Please perform a search of the narratives (Investigative Notes/Remarks) within offense and incident reports for incidents that include any of the following keywords and phrases: ("Road rage" OR "Traffic dispute" OR "Aggressive driving" OR "Reckless driving") AND ("Firearm" OR "gun" OR "shots fired" OR "shot fired" OR "brandishing" OR "gun pointed" OR "pointed gun")

####

PART 3: EXISTING DATA & LOGS

Please provide any existing reports, spreadsheets, or databases compiled by OSHP that track shooting incidents, road rage, or felonious assaults on Ohio highways for the years 2023–2025.

####

FORMAT OF RECORDS REQUESTED:
-- Summary Data: If possible, please provide a summary of all responsive cases in a structured data format (e.g., Excel or CSV) containing the case/incident number, date, time, location (county, highway/route, and nearest mile marker/exit), and all offenses charged.
-- Complete Reports: For each responsive case, please provide the complete initial Incident Report and any narrative supplements.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Chip Brownlee

Please provide any existing reports, spreadsheets, or databases compiled by OSHP that track shooting incidents, road rage, or felonious assaults on Ohio highways for the years 2023–2025. 

#### 

FORMAT OF RECORDS REQUESTED: 
-- Summary Data: If possible, please provide a summary of all responsive cases in a structured data format (e.g., Excel or CSV) containing the case/incident number, date, time, location (county, highway/route, and nearest mile marker/exit), and all offenses charged. 
-- Complete Reports: For each responsive case, please provide the complete initial Incident Report and any narrative supplements. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days. 

Sincerely, 

Chip Brownlee 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2210846/ 
Your request will be sent to the relevant department(s) to locate the records you seek. Requests are processed in the order in which they are received; please do not submit duplicate entries for the same information. You will be contacted about the availability and/or provided with copies of the records in question based on your selected preferred method of delivery. PLEASE NOTE: The Ohio Public Records Act codified in R.C. Chapter 149 does not require a governmental body to create new information or records that do not already exist or are beyond state records retention schedules. 
 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will be contacted when your request has been completed. 
 
 
Again, thank you for using the Ohio Department of Public Safety - Public Records Center. Effective July 1, 2025, the Ohio State Highway Patrol will assess a fee of $38.90 per hour of video requested. This fee is the cost associated with reviewing, blurring, redacting, uploading, and producing the video records (R.C. 149.43(B)(1)). Once we receive the requested video recordings from the post, if any, an invoice shall be provided to you with the associated costs and must be paid prior to processing the videos. If an invoice is not paid within 30 days, the invoice will be cancelled and the request for videos will be closed. All other items contained in the request will still be processed and released in accordance with Ohio Public Records law regardless of whether an invoice is paid. For example, a requester who asks for body cam video, a case report, and a training record but does not pay the video invoice within 30 days will still receive the case report and training record but the video will not be processed and released. 
Ohio Department of Public Safety

title: request for civil commitment data

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: request for civil commitment data
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

For the most recent date available, I am requesting the number of people who are in civil detention or civil commitment in New Jersey. Specifically, I request the following data as of the most recent date available:

1) the total number of people civilly committed in New Jersey by sex (typically people found "not guilty by reason of insanity" or "guilty but mentally ill"); and,
2) the number of people civilly detained in New Jersey by sex (typically people being evaluated or treated for incompetency to stand trial).

If this data is not available by sex, I request the total numbers regardless of sex.
If this data is held by another state agency, I request the name of that agency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emily Widra

title: NYC AI Chatbot (Governance, Authorization & Procurement Artifacts)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: NYC AI Chatbot (Governance, Authorization & Procurement Artifacts)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

The following records related to the NYC AI Chatbot from program inception to current:

* Records approving the creation, pilot, or deployment of the chatbot
* Project charters, decision memos, or internal proposals
* Contracts, MOUs, MSAs, SOWs, and amendments with vendors or partners
* Procurement documents (RFPs, RFIs, bids, evaluations, scoring sheets)
* Funding records (budgets, invoices, payments, cost projections)
* Data inventories (if available)

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brandon Galbraith
